item.title: 𝗕𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗺𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: neuro experiments *fix context* as much as possible as per good experimental control. But if brain processes are strongly context dependent, we need to flip the strategy around or at the very least do both. Working hypothesis: radical context dependence.
item.description: 𝗕𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗺𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: neuro experiments *fix context* as much as possible as per good experimental control. But if brain processes are strongly context dependent, we need to flip the strategy around or at the very least do both. Working hypothesis: radical context dependence.
item.content:encoded: 𝗕𝗿𝗮𝗶𝗻 𝗺𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴: neuro experiments *fix context* as much as possible as per good experimental control. But if brain processes are strongly context dependent, we need to flip the strategy around or at the very least do both. Working hypothesis: radical context dependence.

item.title: Johnson has a blue belt in Brazilian jiujitsu, a sport she took up at Duke. She joined the jiujitsu club to fight depression, but found a welcoming community, practical self-defense training, and lessons that helped her grow professionally. (8/9) https://t.co/IF8z6hF5Qy

item.title: “Jiujitsu is ultimately the art of physical problem-solving under conditions of extreme stress. It has taught me how to react logically & think my way through the steps needed to escape uncomfortable situations. In short, jiujitsu makes me a better scientist,” Johnson says. (9/9)

item.title:
2/3) Since then, we've been wondering:
A: Is there any way to experimentally test for the synaptic distance function used by the brain?
B: Would the brain really use a Euclidean distance function in synaptic weight space, or is there a more plausible alternative?
item.description:
2/3) Since then, we've been wondering:
A: Is there any way to experimentally test for the synaptic distance function used by the brain?
B: Would the brain really use a Euclidean distance function in synaptic weight space, or is there a more plausible alternative?
item.content:encoded: 2/3) Since then, we've been wondering: A: Is there any way to experimentally test for the synaptic distance function used by the brain? B: Would the brain really use a Euclidean distance function in synaptic weight space, or is there a more plausible alternative?

item.title:
3/3) @rmnpogodin delivers a wonderful set of proofs and experiments here to answer question A.
tl;dr: He shows that you can use the distribution of synaptic weights to test between different potential synaptic distance functions.
Stay tuned for an answer to question B... 🙂
